articles.headline: Retailers Push Sales, and Normalcy, but Economic Uncertainty Looms
articles.snippet: Black Friday deals returned, drawing shoppers back into stores, but inflation worries left many companies unsure what the holiday shopping season would look like.
articles.abstract: Black Friday deals returned, drawing shoppers back into stores, but inflation worries left many companies unsure what the holiday shopping season would look like.
articles.lead_paragraph: After two years of pandemic improvisation and in-store restrictions, this year’s Black Friday felt like a return to normalcy.

articles.headline: U.S. and NATO Scramble to Arm Ukraine and Refill Their Own Arsenals
articles.snippet: The West thought an artillery and tank war in Europe would never happen again and shrank weapons stockpiles. It was wrong.
articles.abstract: The West thought an artillery and tank war in Europe would never happen again and shrank weapons stockpiles. It was wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — When the Soviet Union collapsed, European nations grabbed the “peace dividend,” drastically shrinking their defense budgets, their armies and their arsenals.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Lara Jakes

articles.headline: A Rising Star in the Biden Administration Faces a $100 Billion Test
articles.snippet: Gina Raimondo, the commerce secretary, has made a career of tackling increasingly larger challenges. Could the next one be too big?
articles.abstract: Gina Raimondo, the commerce secretary, has made a career of tackling increasingly larger challenges. Could the next one be too big?
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind. — Gina Raimondo, the commerce secretary, was meeting with students at Purdue University in September when she spotted a familiar face. Ms. Raimondo beamed as she greeted the chief executive of SkyWater Technology, a chip company that had announced plans to build a $1.8 billion manufacturing facility next to the Purdue campus.

articles.headline: The Excitement Around E-Sports Is Growing. But Where Are the Profits?
articles.snippet: Traditional sports owners who invested in competitive video gaming say the money isn’t flowing in as quickly as they had expected.
articles.abstract: Traditional sports owners who invested in competitive video gaming say the money isn’t flowing in as quickly as they had expected.
articles.lead_paragraph: It had been more than three hours of tense, back-and-forth combat — projected across the massive Jumbotron at San Francisco’s Chase Center — when the sellout crowd, thumping together inflatable thundersticks and yelling with excitement, sensed victory was at hand.

articles.headline: At Protests, Guns Are Doing the Talking
articles.snippet: Armed Americans, often pushing a right-wing agenda, are increasingly using open-carry laws to intimidate opponents and shut down debate.
articles.abstract: Armed Americans, often pushing a right-wing agenda, are increasingly using open-carry laws to intimidate opponents and shut down debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Across the country, openly carrying a gun in public is no longer just an exercise in self-defense — increasingly it is a soapbox for elevating one’s voice and, just as often, quieting someone else’s.

articles.headline: It’s Public Land. But the Public Can’t Reach It.
articles.snippet: A navigation app that illuminates public land within privately held property has supercharged the question of who gets to go where.
articles.abstract: A navigation app that illuminates public land within privately held property has supercharged the question of who gets to go where.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first time I showed the app to someone who had never used it, I had to gently extract my phone from the person’s hand. This happened the second time, too, and was followed by an email requesting the name of “that mapping program.”

articles.headline: They Were Surrogates. Now They Must Raise the Children.
articles.snippet: In Cambodia’s weak legal system, surrogacy exists in a gray market, endangering all involved when political conditions suddenly shift and criminal charges follow.
articles.abstract: In Cambodia’s weak legal system, surrogacy exists in a gray market, endangering all involved when political conditions suddenly shift and criminal charges follow.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — The baby was not hers, not really.
articles.byline: By Hannah Beech and Nadia Shira Cohen

articles.headline: As Gen X and Boomers Age, They Confront Living Alone
articles.snippet: More older Americans are living by themselves than ever before. That shift presents issues on housing, health care and personal finance.
articles.abstract: More older Americans are living by themselves than ever before. That shift presents issues on housing, health care and personal finance.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jay Miles has lived his 52 years without marriage or children, which has suited his creative ambitions as a videographer in Connecticut and, he said, his mix of “independence and stubbornness.” But he worries about who will take care of him as he gets older.
articles.byline: By Dana Goldstein and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: Business Travel’s Rebound Is Being Hit by a Slowing Economy
articles.snippet: By the early fall, domestic business travel was back up to nearly two-thirds of its prepandemic level. But companies have now begun to cut back.
articles.abstract: By the early fall, domestic business travel was back up to nearly two-thirds of its prepandemic level. But companies have now begun to cut back.
articles.lead_paragraph: Business travel came back this year more strongly than most industry analysts had predicted in the depths of the pandemic, with domestic travel rebounding by this fall to about two-thirds of the 2019 level.

articles.headline: He Never Denied Selling Drugs. But Britain Says He’s a Slave Master, Too.
articles.snippet: A law written to prevent human trafficking is being wielded against low-level drug dealers. The effects are long-lasting.
articles.abstract: A law written to prevent human trafficking is being wielded against low-level drug dealers. The effects are long-lasting.
articles.lead_paragraph: Glodi Wabelua was determined to come out different this time: “More humble. More quiet.” He was 28 and this was his third release from prison.

articles.headline: Giant Wind Farms Arise Off Scotland, Easing the Pain of Oil’s Decline
articles.snippet: Oil and gas workers, losing their jobs as fossil fuel investment wanes, find work in the wind energy business.
articles.abstract: Oil and gas workers, losing their jobs as fossil fuel investment wanes, find work in the wind energy business.
articles.lead_paragraph: The pilot of the nearly 80-foot work boat gunned its powerful engines, pinning the bow against the base of a towering wind turbine in the smooth North Sea. Three men in yellow and orange outfits stepped  onto metal rungs and started slowly scaling the nearly 300-foot structure, past the huge blades that help send electricity to Scotland.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Francesca Jones

articles.headline: After Deadly Blaze, Surge of Defiance Against China’s Covid Policies
articles.snippet: Protests became rare once the government cut off most routes to collective action. But ubiquitous Covid rules, bringing shared suffering, have created a focus for anger.
articles.abstract: Protests became rare once the government cut off most routes to collective action. But ubiquitous Covid rules, bringing shared suffering, have created a focus for anger.
articles.lead_paragraph: The fire began with a faulty power strip in a bedroom on the 15th floor of an apartment building in China’s far west. Firefighters spent three hours putting it out — too slow to prevent at least 10 deaths — and what might have remained an isolated accident turned into a tragedy and a political headache for local leaders.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley, Vivian Wang, Chang Che and Amy Chang Chien

articles.headline: In Ukraine, Bakhmut Becomes a Bloody Vortex for 2 Militaries
articles.snippet: Even as they have celebrated successes elsewhere, Ukrainian forces in one small eastern city have endured relentless Russian attacks. And the struggle to hold it is only intensifying.
articles.abstract: Even as they have celebrated successes elsewhere, Ukrainian forces in one small eastern city have endured relentless Russian attacks. And the struggle to hold it is only intensifying.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAKHMUT, Ukraine — For almost an hour, the stream of Ukrainian casualties in the eastern city of Bakhmut seemed unending: Ambulances, an armored personnel carrier and private vehicles all screamed to a halt, one after another, and disgorged the wounded in front of the city’s only military hospital.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

articles.headline: Why Retailers Are Trying Extra Hard to Woo Holiday Shoppers
articles.snippet: With an economic slowdown a distinct possibility, stores hope customers’ willingness to open their wallets will last through the season.
articles.abstract: With an economic slowdown a distinct possibility, stores hope customers’ willingness to open their wallets will last through the season.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amazon held what amounted to an extra Prime Day in October, blanketing its site with deals. Best Buy rolled out Black Friday-level sales last month. And on Friday, Kohl’s entered the first 200 people to walk into each of its stores into a sweepstakes, with prizes including gift cards to Sephora and a family trip to a Legoland resort.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Jordyn Holman

articles.headline: Have the Anticapitalists Reached Harvard Business School?
articles.snippet: Social justice joins discounted cash flows on the syllabus as essential knowledge for aspiring corporate leaders.
articles.abstract: Social justice joins discounted cash flows on the syllabus as essential knowledge for aspiring corporate leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: At Harvard Business School, inside a seminar room with a smattering of button-down shirts and puffy fall jackets, a group of future corporate managers were talking about capitalism. What makes capitalism truly and purely capitalism? What are its essential components? Property rights. Financial markets.

articles.headline: Biden Helped Democrats Avert a ’22 Disaster. What About ’24?
articles.snippet: A stronger-than-expected midterm showing has quieted the party’s public hand-wringing about a re-election campaign for President Biden. But it hasn’t put those worries to rest.
articles.abstract: A stronger-than-expected midterm showing has quieted the party’s public hand-wringing about a re-election campaign for President Biden. But it hasn’t put those worries to rest.
articles.lead_paragraph: Expecting a cataclysmic midterm election, many Democrats had been bracing for an end-of-year reckoning with whether President Biden, who once declared himself a “bridge” to a new generation, should give way to a new 2024 standard-bearer.

articles.headline: Crypto Lender BlockFi Files for Bankruptcy as FTX Fallout Spreads
articles.snippet: BlockFi was entangled with FTX, and its stability was thrust into uncertainty after FTX collapsed.
articles.abstract: BlockFi was entangled with FTX, and its stability was thrust into uncertainty after FTX collapsed.
articles.lead_paragraph: BlockFi, a cryptocurrency lender that targeted ordinary investors eager for a piece of the crypto mania, filed for bankruptcy on Monday, felled by its financial ties to FTX, the embattled exchange whose recent downfall has shaken the crypto industry to its core.
articles.byline: By Lauren Hirsch, David Yaffe-Bellany and Ephrat Livni
